faqs.question: Can foreigners buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Yes, foreigners can purchase property in Spain without restrictions. EU citizens have the same rights as Spanish nationals. Non-EU citizens may require an NIE (Spanish Tax Identification Number) and should verify residency requirements. Professional legal assistance ensures compliance with regulations, mortgage requirements, and tax obligations. VICTORIA PLAYA can provide referrals to English-speaking legal and financial advisors specializing in international property transactions.

faqs.question: What are the costs of buying property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Beyond the purchase price, expect additional costs including: Transfer Tax (6-10% depending on region), Notary fees (0.5-1%), Property Registration (0.1%), Legal fees (1-2%), and Mortgage costs if financing (1-3%). In Alicante, Transfer Tax is typically 10%. These costs should be budgeted separately from the €499,000 purchase price. Our team can provide detailed cost breakdowns.

faqs.question: Do I need a visa to buy property in Spain?
faqs.answer: Property purchase does not automatically grant residency or visa rights. EU citizens enjoy freedom of movement. Non-EU citizens may pursue Golden Visa (€500,000+ investment), Digital Nomad Visa, or other residency pathways. Consult Spanish embassy guidelines for your nationality. Property ownership and residency are separate legal matters requiring independent processing.

faqs.question: How much are property taxes in Spain?
faqs.answer: Annual property taxes in Spain include: IBI (Property Tax, 0.4-1.1% of cadastral value), which for a €499,000 property averages €1,500-2,500 annually. Non-resident owners pay additional taxes on rental income (19-45%) and capital gains. However, Spain offers non-habitual resident (NHR) tax benefits for new residents (6 years). Consult a Spanish tax advisor to optimize your tax position based on residency status and income sources.
